SP.P: And I detest your three chairs and a bolster.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: You do, do you!—then let me see—what—if you go on a mile further, to the Buck's Head; the old Buck's Head on the hill, one of the best inns in the whole county?

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: O ho! so we have escaped an adventure for This night, however.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: (Apart to Tony) Sure, you ben't sending them to your father's as an inn, be you?

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Mum, you fool you. Let them find that out. (To them.) You have only to keep on straight for∣ward, till you come to a large old house by the road side. You'll see a pair of large horns over the door. That's the sign. Drive up the yard, and call stoutly about you.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Sir, we are obliged to you. The servants can't, miss the way?

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: No, no: but I tell you though, the landlord is rich, and going to leave off business; so he wants to be thought a gentleman, saving your presence, he! he! he! He'll be for giving you his company, and ecod if you mind him, he'll persuade you that his mother was an alderman, and his aunt a justice of peace.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: A troublesome old blade to be sure; but a keeps as good wines and beds as any in the whole coun∣try.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Well, if he supplies us with these, we shall want no further connection. We are to turn to the right, did you say?

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: No, no; straight forward. I'll just step myself, and shew you a piece of the way. (To the landlord) Mum.

SP.SPEAKER: LANDLORD.
SP.P: Ah, bless your heart, for a sweet, pleasant—damn'd mischievous son of a whore.

DIV1.HEAD: ACT THE SECOND.
DIV1.STAGE: Enter HARDCASTLE, followed by three or four aukward servants.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: WELL, I hope you're perfect in the table ex∣ercise I have been teaching you these three days. You all know your posts and your places, and can shew that you have been used to good company, without ever stirring from home.

SP.SPEAKER: OMNES.
SP.P: Aye, aye.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: When company comes, you are not to pop out and stare, and then run in again, like frighted rabbits in a warren.

SP.SPEAKER: OMNES.
SP.P: No, no.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P:
You, Diggory, whom I have taken from the barn, are to make a shew at the side-table; and you, Ro∣ger, whom I have advanced from the plough, are to
place yourself behind my chair. But you're not to stand so, with your hands in your pockets. Take your hands from your pockets, Roger; and from your head, you blockhead you. See how Diggory carries his hands. They're a little too stiff, indeed, but that's no great matter.

SP.SPEAKER: DIGGORY.
SP.P: Aye, mind how I hold them. I learned to hold my hands this way, when I was upon drill for the militia. And so being upon drill—

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: You must not be so talkative, Diggory. You must be all attention to the guests. You must hear us talk, and not think of talking; you must see us drink, and not think of drinking; you must see us eat, and not think of eating.

SP.SPEAKER: DIGGORY.
SP.P: By the laws, your worship, that's parfectly unpos∣sible. Whenever Diggory sees yeating going for∣ward, ecod he's always wishing for a mouthful him∣self.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Blockhead! Is not a belly-full in the kitchen as good as a belly-full in the parlour? Stay your sto∣mach with that reflection.

SP.SPEAKER: DIGGORY.
SP.P: Ecod I thank your worship, I'll make a shift to stay my stomach with a slice of cold beef in the pantry.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Diggory, you are too talkative. Then if I hap∣pen to say a good thing, or tell a good story at ta∣ble, you must not all burst out a-laughing as if you made part of the company.

SP.SPEAKER: DIGGORY.
SP.P: Then ecod your worship must not tell the story of ould grouse in the gun room: I can't help laughing at that—he! he! he!—for the soul of me. We have laughed at that these twenty years—ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! The story is a good one. Well, honest Diggory, you may laugh at that—but still remember to be attentive. Suppose one of the com∣pany should call for a glass of wine, how will you behave? A glass of wine, Sir, if you please, (To Diggory)—Eh, why don't you move?

SP.SPEAKER: DIGGORY.
SP.P: Ecod, your worship, I never have courage till I see the eatables and drinkables brought upo' the ta∣ble, and then I'm as bauld as a lion.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: What, will nobody move?

SP.SPEAKER: FIRST SERVANT.
SP.P: I'm not to leave this place.

SP.SPEAKER: SECOND SERVANT.
SP.P: I'm sure it's no place of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: THIRD SERVANT.
SP.P: Nor mine, for sartain.

SP.SPEAKER: DIGGORY.
SP.P: Wauns, and I'm sure it canna be mine.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: You numbskulls! and so while, like your betters, you are quarrelling for places, the guests must be starved. O you dunces! I find I must begin all over again.—But don't I hear a coach drive into the yard? To your posts, you blockheads. I'll go in the mean time and give my old friend's son a hearty reception at the gate.

SP.SPEAKER: DIGGORY.
SP.P: By the elevens, my place is gone quite out of my head.

SP.SPEAKER: ROGER.
SP.P: I know that my place is to be every where.

SP.SPEAKER: FIRST SERVANT.
SP.P: Where the devil is mine?

SP.SPEAKER: SECOND SERVANT.
SP.P: MY pleace is to be no where at all; and so ize go about my business.

DIV1.STAGE: [Exeunt servants, running about as if frighted, different ways.
Enter SERVANT with Candles, shewing in MAR∣LOW and HASTINGS.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Welcome, gentlemen, very welcome! This way.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: After the disappointments of the day, welcome Once more, Charles, to the comforts of a clean room and a good fire. Upon my word, a very well∣looking house; antique but creditable.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: The usual fate of a large mansion. Having first ruined the master by good housekeeping, it at last comes to levy contributions as an inn.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: As you say, we passengers are to be taxed to pay all these fineries. I have often seen a good side∣board, or a marble chimney-piece, though not ac∣tually put in the bill, inflame a reckoning con∣foundedly.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Travellers, George, must pay in all places. The only difference is, that in good inns, you pay dearly for luxuries; in bad inns, you are fleeced and starved.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: You have lived pretty much among them. In truth, I have been often surprised, that you who have seen so much of the world, with your natural good sense, and your many opportunities, could ne∣ver yet acquire a requite share of assurance.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P:
The Englishman's malady. But tell me, George, where ould I have learned that assurance you talk
of? My life has been chiefly spent in a college, or an inn, in seclusion from that lovely part of the creation that chiefly teach men confidence. I don't know that I was ever familiarly acquainted with a single modest woman—except my mother—But a∣mong females of another class you know—

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Aye, among them you are impudent enough of all conscience.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: They are of us, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: But in the company of women of reputation I ne∣ver saw such an idiot, such a trembler; you look for all the world as if you wanted an opportunity of stealing out of the room.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Why, man, that's because I do want to steal out of the room. Faith, I have often formed a resolution to break the ice, and rattle away at any rate. But I don't know how, a single glance from a pair of fine eyes has totally overset my resolution. An im∣pudent fellow may counterfeit modesty, but I'll be hanged if a modest man can ever counterfeit impu∣dence.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: If you could but say half the fine things to them that I have heard you lavish upon the bar-maid of an inn, or even a college bed-maker—

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Why, George, I can't say fine things to them; they freeze, they petrify me. They may talk of a comet, or a burning mountain, or some such baga∣telle. But to me, a Modest woman, drest out in all her finery, is the most tremendous object of the whole creation.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! At this rate, man, how can you ever expect to marry?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Never, unless, as among kings and princes, my bride were to be courted by proxy. If, indeed, like an eastern bridegroom, one were to be intro∣duced to a wife he never saw before, it might be endured. But to go through all the terrors of a formal courtship, together with the episode of aunts, grandmothers, and cousins, and at last to blurt out the broad staring question of, madam, will you mar∣ry me? No, no, that's a strain much above me, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: I pity you. But how do you intend behaving to the lady you are come down to visit at the request of your father?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: As I behave to all other ladies. Bow very low. Answer yes, or no, to all her demands—But for the rest, I don't think I shall venture to look in her face, till I see my father's again.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: I'm surprised that one who is so warm a friend can be so cool a lover.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: To be explicit, my dear Hastings, my chief in∣ducement down was to be instrumental in forward∣ing your happiness, not my own. Miss Neville loves you, the family don't know you, as my friend you are sure of a reception, and let honour do the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: My dear Marlow! But I'll suppress the emotion. Were I a wretch, meanly seeking to carry off a for∣tune, you should be the last man in the world I would apply to for assistance. But Miss Neville's person is all I ask, and that is mine, both from her deceased father's consent, and her own inclination.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Happy man! You have talents and art to capti∣vate any woman. I'm doom'd to adore the sex, and yet to converse with the only part of it I despise. This stammer in my address, and this aukward pre∣possessing visage of mine, can never permit me to soar above the reach of a milliner's 'prentice, or one of the duchesses of Drury-lane. Pshaw! this fel∣low here to interrupt us.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Gentlemen, once more you are heartily welcome. Which is Mr. Marlow? Sir, you're heartily wel∣come. It's not my way, you see, to receive my friends with my back to the fire. I like to give them a hearty reception in the old style at my gate. I like to see their horses and trunks taken care of.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW (aside.)
SP.P: He has got our names from the servants already. (To him) We approve your caution and hospitality, Sir. (To Hastings) I have been thinking, George, of changing our travelling dresses in the morning. I am grown confoundedly ashamed of mine.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I beg, Mr. Marlow, you'll use no ceremony in this house.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: I fancy, George, you're right: the first blow is half the battle. I intend opening the campaign with the white and gold.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Mr. Marlow—Mr. Hastings—gentlemen—pray be under no constraint in this house. This is Li∣berty-hall, gentlemen. You may do just as you please here.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P:
Yet, George, if we open the campaign too fiercely at first, we may want ammunition before it
is over. I think to reserve the embroidery to secure a retreat.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Your talking of a retreat, Mr. Marlow, puts me in wind of the duke of Marlborough, when we went to besiege Denain. He first summoned the garrison.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Don't you think the ventre dór waistcoat will do with the plain brown?

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: He first summoned the garrison, which might con∣sist of about five thousand men—

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: I think not: brown and yellow mix but very poorly.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I say, gentlemen, as I was telling you, he sum∣moned The garrison, which might consist of about five thousand men—

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: The girls like finery.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P:
Which might consist of about five thousand men, well appointed with stores ammunition, and other implements of war. Now, says the duke of Marl∣borough to George Brooks, that stood next to him—you must have heard of George Brooks—I'll
pawn my dukedom, says he, but I take that garri∣son without spilling a drop of blood. So—

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: What, my good friend, if you gave us a glass of punch in the mean time, it would help us to carry on the siege with vigour.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Punch, Sir! (Aside) This is the most unaccount∣able kind of modesty I ever met with.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, punch. A glass of warm punch, after our journey, will be comfortable. This is Liber∣ty-hall, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Here's cup, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (Aside) So this fellow, in his Liberty-hall, will only let us have just what he pleases.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (Taking the cup) I hope you'll find it to your mind. I have prepared it with my own hands, and I believe you'll own the ingredients are tolerable. Will you be so good as to pledge me, Sir? Here, Mr. Marlow, here is to our better acquaintance. (Drinks.)

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (Aside) A very impudent fellow this! but he's a character and I'll humour him a little. Sir, my ser∣vice to you. (Drinks.)

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: (Aside) I see this fellow wants to give us his com∣pany, and forgets that he's an innkeeper, before he has learned to be a gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: From the excellence of your cup, my old friend, I suppose you have a good deal of business in this part of the country. Warm work, now and then, at elections, I suppose.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: No, Sir, I have long given that work over. Since our betters have hit upon the expedient of electing each other, there is no business 'for us that sell ale.'

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: So, then you have no turn for politics I find.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Not in the least. There was a time, indeed, I fretted myself about the mistakes of government, like other people; but finding myself every day grow more angry, and the government growing no better, I left it to mend itself. Since that, I no more trouble my head about Heyder Ally or Ally Cawn, than about Ally Croaker. Sir, my service to you.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: So that with eating above stairs, and drinking be∣low, with receiving your friends within, and amus∣ing them without, you lead a good pleasant bustling life of it.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I do stir about a great deal, that's certain. Half the differences of the parish are adjusted in this very parlour.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (After drinking) And you have an argument in your cup, old gentleman, better than any in West∣minster-hall.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Aye, young gentleman, that, and a little philo∣sophy.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (Aside.) Well, this is the first time I ever heard of an innkeeper's philosophy.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: So then, like an experienced general, you attack them on every quarter. If you find their reason ma∣nageable, you attack it with your philosophy; if you find they have no reason, you attack them with this. Here's your health, my philosopher. (Drinks.)

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Good, very good, thank you; ha! ha! Your generalship puts me in mind of prince Eugene, when he fought the Turks at the battle of Belgrade. You shall hear.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Instead of the battle of Belgrade, I believe it's almost time to talk about supper. What has your philosophy got in the house for supper?

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: For supper, Sir! (Aside) Was ever such a request to a man in his own house!

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, supper, Sir; I begin to feel an appe∣tite. I shall make dev'lish work to-night in the larder, I promise you.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (Aside) Such a brazen dog sure never my eyes be∣held. (To him) Why really, Sir, as for supper I can't well tell. My Dorothy, and the cook-maid, settle these things between them. I leave these kind of things entirely to then.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Yon do, do you?

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Entirely. By-the-bye, I believe they are in ac∣tual consultation upon what's for supper this mo∣ment in the kitchen.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Then I beg they'll admit me as one of their pri∣vy council. It's a way I have got. When I travel, I always chuse to regulate my own supper. Let the cook be called. No offence I hope, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: O no, Sir, none in the least; yet I don't know how: our Bridget, the cook-maid, is not very com∣municative upon these occasions. Should we send for her, she might scold us all out of the house.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Let's see your list of the larder then. I ask it as a favour. I always match my appetite to my bill of fare.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (To Hardcastle, who looks at them with surprise) Sir, he's very right, and it's my way too.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Sir, you have a right to command here. Here, Roger, bring us the bill of fare for to-night's sup∣per. I believe it's drawn out. Your manner, Mr. Hastings, puts me in mind of my uncle, colonel Wallop. It was a saying of his, that no man was sure of his supper till he had eaten it.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: (Aside) All upon the high ropes! His uncle a colonel! We shall soon hear of his mother being a justice of peace. But let's hear the bill of fare.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (Perusing) What's here? For the first course; for the second course; for the desert. The devil, Sir, do you think we have brought down the whole joiners company, or the corporation of Bedford, to eat up such a supper? Two or three little things, clean and comfortable, will do.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: But, let's hear it.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (Reading) For the first course at the top, a pig, and pruin sauce.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Damn your pig, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: And damn your pruin sauce, say I.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: And yet, gentlemen, to men that are hungry, pig, with pruin sauce, is very good eating.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: At the bottom, a calve's tongue and brains.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Let your brains be knock'd out, my good Sir; I don't like them.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Or you may clap them on a plate by themselves.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (Aside) Their impudence confounds me. (To them) Gentlemen, you are my guests, make what alterations you please. Is there any thing else you wish to retrench or alter, gentlemen?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Item. A pork pye, a boiled rabbit and sausages, a Florentine, a shaking pudding, and a dish of tiff—taff—taffety cream!

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P:
Confound your made dishes, I shall be as much at a loss in this house as at a green and yellow din∣ner
at the French ambassador's table. I'm for plain eating.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I'm sorry, gentlemen, that I have nothing you like, but if there be any thing you have a particular fancy to—

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Why, really, Sir, your bill of fare is so exquisite, that any one part of it is full as good as another. Send us what you please. So much for supper. And now to see that our beds are air'd, and proper∣ly taken care of.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I entreat you'll leave all that to me. You shall not stir a step.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Leave that to you! I protest, Sir, you must ex∣cuse me, I always look to these things myself.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I must insist, Sir, you'll make yourself easy on that head.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: You see I'm resolved on it. (Aside.) A very trou∣blesome fellow this, as ever I met with.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Well, Sir, I'm resolved at least to attend you. (Aside) This may be modern modesty, but I never saw any thing look so like old-fashioned impudence.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS, solus.
SP.P: So I find this fellow's civilities begin to grow trou∣blesome. But who can be angry at those assiduities Which are meant to please him? Ha! what do I see? Miss Neville, by all that's happy!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: My dear Hastings! To what unexpected good fortune? to what accident, am I to ascribe this hap∣py meeting?

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Rather let me ask the same question, as I could never have hoped to meet my dearest Constance at an inn.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: An inn! sure you mistake! my aunt, my guardi∣an, lives here. What could induce you to think this hóuse an inn?

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: My friend, Mr. Marlow, with whom I came down, and I, have been sent here as to an inn, I assure you. A young fellow whom we accidentally met at a house hard by directed us hither.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: Certainly it must be one of my hopeful cousin's tricks, of whom you have heard me talk so often, ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: He whom your aunt intends for you? he of whom I have such just apprehensions?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: You have nothing to fear from him, I assure you. You'd adore him if you knew how heartily he de∣spises me. My aunt knows it too, and has under∣taken to court me for him, and actually begins to think she has made a conquest.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Thou dear dissembler! You must know, my Constance, I have just seized this happy oppor∣tunity of my friend's visit here to get admittance into the family. The horses that carried us down are now fatigued with their journey, but they'll soon be refreshed; and then, if my dearest girl will trust in her faithful Hastings, we shall soon be landed, in France, where even among slaves the laws of marriage are respected.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: I have Often told you, that, though ready to obey you, I yet should leave my little fortune behind with reluctance. The greatest part of it was left me by my uncle, the India director, and chiefly consists in jewels. I have been for some time per∣suading my aunt to let me wear them. I fancy I'm very near succeeding. The instant they are put into my possession you shall find me ready to make them and myself yours.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Perish the baubles! Your person is all I desire. In the mean time, my friend Marlow must not be let into his mistake. I know the strange reserve of his temper is such, that if abruptly informed of it, he would instanly quit die house before our plan was ripe for execution.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: But how shall we keep him in the deception? Miss Hardcastle is just returned from walking; what if we still continue to deceive him?—This, this way—

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: The assiduities of these good people teize me be∣yond bearing. My host seems to think it ill man∣ners to leave me alone, and so he claps not only himself but his old-fashioned wife on my back. They talk of coming to sup with us too; and then, I suppose, we are to run the gauntlet through all the rest of the family.—What have we got here!—

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: My dear Charles! Let me congratulate you!—The most fortunate accident!—Who do you think is just alighted?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Cannot guess.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Our mistresses, boy, Miss Hardcastle and Miss Ne∣ville. Give me leave to introduce Miss Constance Neville to your acquaintance. Happening to dine in the neighbourhood, they called, on their return, to take fresh horses here. Miss Hardcastle has just stept into the next room, and will be back in an instant. Wasn't it lucky? eh!

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (Aside) I have been mortified enough of all con∣science, and here comes something to complete my embarrassment.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Well! but was'nt it the most fortunate thing in the world?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Oh! yes. Very fortunate—a most joyful en∣counter—But our dresses, George, you know are in disorder—What if we should postpone the happiness 'till to-morrow?—To-morrow at her own house—It will be every bit as convenient—and rather more respectful—To-morrow let it be. [Offering to go.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: By no means, Sir. Your ceremony will displease her. The disorder of your dress will shew the ar∣dour of your impatience. Besides, she knows you are in the house, and will permit you to see her.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: O! the devil! how shall I support it? hem! hem! Hastings, you must not go. You are to as∣sist me, you know. I shall be confoundedly ridicu∣lous. Yet, hang it! I'll take courage. Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Pshaw, man! it's but the first plunge, and all's over. She's but a woman, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: And of all women, she that I dread most to en∣counter!

DIV1.STAGE: Enter Miss HARDCASTLE, as returned from walking, a bonnet, &c.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS, introducing them.
SP.P: Miss Hardcastle, Mr. Marlow. I'm proud of bringing two persons of such merit together, that only want to know, to esteem each other.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (Aside) Now, for meeting my modest gentleman with a demure face, and quite in his own manner. (After a pause, in which be appears very uneasy and disconcerted.) I'm glad of your safe arrival, Sir—I'm told you had some accidents by the way.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Only a few, madam. Yes, we had some. Yes, madam, a good many accidents, but should be sorry—madam—or rather glad of any accidents—that are so agreeably concluded. Hem!

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: (To him) You never spoke better in your whole life. Keep it up, and I'll insure you the victory.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I'm afraid you flatter, Sir. You that have seen so much of the finest company can find little enter∣tainment in an obscure corner of the country.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (Gathering courage) I have lived, indeed, in the world, madam; but I have kept very little com∣pany. I have been but an observer upon life, ma∣dam, while others were enjoying it.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: But that, I am told, is the way to enjoy it at last.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: (To him) Cicero never spoke better. Once more, and you are confirmed in assurance for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (To him) Hem! stand by me then, and when I'm down, throw in a word or two to set me up again.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: An observer, like you, upon life, were, I fear, disagreeably employed, since you must have had much more to censure than to approve.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Pardon me, madam. I was always willing to be amused. The folly of most people is rather an ob∣ject of mirth than uneasiness.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: (To him) Bravo, bravo. Never spoke so well in your whole life. Well! Miss Hardcastle, I see that you and Mr. Marlow are going to be very good company. I believe our being here will but em∣barrass the interview.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Not in the least, Mr. Hastings. We like your company of all things. (To him) Zounds! George, sure you won't go? how can you leave us?

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Our presence will but spoil conversation. so we'll retire to the next room. (To him) Yon don't consi∣der, man, that we are to manage a little tête-à-tête of our own.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (After a pause I But you have not been wholly an observer, I presume, Sir: the ladies I should hope have employed some part of your addresses.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (Relapsing into timidity) Pardon me, madam, I—I—I—as yet have studied—only—to—deserve them.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: And that, some say, is the very worst way to ob∣tain them.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Perhaps so madam. But I love to converse only with the more grave and sensible part Of the sex.—But I'm afraid I grow tiresome.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Not at all, Sir; there is nothing I like so much as grave conversation myself; I could hear it for ever. Indeed I have often been surprised how a man of sentiment could ever admire those light airy pleasures, where nothing reaches the heart.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: It's—a disease—of the mind, madam. In the variety of tastes there must be some who want∣ing a relish—for—um—a—um.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I understand you, Sir. There must be some, who wanting a relish for refined pleasures, pretend to de∣spise what they are incapable of tasting.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: My meaning, madam, but infinitely better ex∣pressed. And I can't help observing—a—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (Aside) Who could ever suppose this fellow im∣pudent upon such occasions. (To him) You were going to observe, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: I was observing, madam—I protest, madam, I forget what I was going to observe.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (Aside) I vow and so do I. (To him) You were observing, Sir, that in this age of hypocrisy some∣thing about hypocrisy, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Yes, madam. In this age of hypocrisy there are few who upon strict inquiry do not—a—a—a—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I understand you perfectly, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (Aside) Egad! and that's more than I do myself.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: You mean that in this hypocritical age there are few that do not condemn in public what they prac∣tise in private, and think they pay every debt to virtue when they praise it.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: True, madam; those who have most virtue in their mouths, have least of it in their bosoms. But I'm sure I tire you, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Not in the least, Sir; there's something so agree∣able and spirited in your manner, such life and force—pray, Sir, go on.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Yes, madam. I was saying—that there are some occasions—when a total want of courage, madam, destroys all the—and puts us—upon a—a—a—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P:
I agree with you entirely, a want of courage upon some occasions assumes the appearance of ignorance
and betrays us when we most want to excel. I beg you'll proceed.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Yes, madam. Morally speaking, madam—But I see Miss Neville expecting us in the next room. I would not intrude for the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I protest, Sir, I never was more agreeably enter∣tained in all my life. Pray go on.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Yes, madam. I was—But she beckons us to join her. Madam, shall I do myself the honour to attend you?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Well then, I'll follow.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (Aside) This pretty smooth dialogue has done for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE, sola.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! Was there ever such a sober senti∣mental interview? I'm certain he scarce look'd in my face the whole time. Yet the fellow, but for his unaccountable bashfulness, is pretty well too. He has good sense, but then so buried in his fears, that it fatigues one more than ignorance. If I could teach him a little confidence, it would be do∣ing somebody that I know of a piece of service. But who is that somebody?—That, faith, is a ques∣tion I can scarce answer.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter TONY and Miss NEVILLE, followed by Mrs. HARDCASTLE and HASTINGS.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: What do you follow me for, cousin Con? I won∣der you're not asham'd to be so very engaging.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: I hope, cousin, one may speak to one's own rela∣tions, and not be to blame.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Aye, but I know what sort of a relation you want to make me though; but it won't do. I tell you, cousin Con, it won't do; so I beg you'll keep your distance, I want no nearer relationship.
She follows, coquetting him to the back scene.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Well! I vow, Mr. Hastings, you are very enter∣taining. There's nothing in the world I love to talk of so much as London, and the fashions, though I was never there myself.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Never there! You amaze me! From your air and manner, I conclude you had been bred all your life either at Ranelagh, St. James's, or Tower Wharf.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P:
O! Sir, you're only pleased to say so. We country persons can have no manner at all. I'm in love with the town, and that serves to raise me
above some of our neighbouring rustics; but who can have a manner, that has never seen the Panthe∣on, the Grotto Gardens, the Borough, and such places where the nobility chiefly resort? All I can do, is to enjoy London at second-hand. I take care to know every tête-à-tête from the scandalous ma∣gazine, and have all the fashions, as they come out, in a letter from the two Miss Rickets of Crooked∣lane. Pray how do you like this head, Mr. Hast∣ings?

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Extremely elegant and degagée, upon my word, madam. your friseur is a Frenchman, I suppose?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I protest I dressed it myself from a print in the la∣dies memorandum-book for the last year.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Indeed! Such a head in a side-box, at the play∣house, would draw as many gazers as my lady may'ress at a city ball.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I vow, since inoculation began, there is no such thing to be seen as a plain woman; so one must dress a little particular, or one may escape in the crowd.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: But that can never be your case, madam, in any dress. (Bowing.)

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Yet, what signifies my dressing when I have such a piece of antiquity by my side as Mr. Hardcastle: all I can say will never argue down a single button from his cloaths. I have often wanted him to throw off his great flaxen wig, and where he was bald, to plaister it over, like my Lord Pately, with powder.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: You are right, madam; for, as among the ladies there are none ugly, so among the men there are none old.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: But what do you think his answer was? Why, with his usual Gothic vivacity, he said I only want∣ed him to throw off his wig to convert it into a tête for my own wearing.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Intolerable! At your age you may wear what you please, and it must become you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Pray, Mr. Hastings, what do you take to be the most fashionable age about town?

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Some time ago, forty was all the mode; but I'm told the ladies intend to bring up fifty for the ensu∣ing winter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Seriously. Then I shall be too young for the fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: No lady begins now to put on jewels 'till she's past forty. For instance, Miss there, in a polite circle, would be considered as a child, as a mere maker of samplers.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: And yet Mrs. Niece thinks herself as much a woman, and is as fond of jewels as the oldest of us all.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Your niece, is she? And that young gentleman, a brother of yours, I should presume?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: My son, Sir. They are contracted to each other. Observe their little sports. They fall in and out ten times a day, as if they were man and wife al∣ready. (To them) Well, Tony, child, what soft things are you saying to your cousin Constance this evening?

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: I have been saying no soft things; but that it's very hard to be followed about so. Ecod! I've not a place in the house now that's left to myself, but the stable.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Never mind him, Con, my dear. He's in ano∣ther story behind your back.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: There's something generous in my cousin's man∣ner. He falls out before faces to be forgiven in private.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: That's a damned confounded—crack.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Ah! he's a sly one. Don't you think they're like each other about the month, Mr. Hastings? The Blenkinsop mouth to a T. They're of a size too. Back to back, my pretties, that Mr. Hastings may see you. Come, Tony.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: You had as good not make me, I tell you.
Measuring.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: O lud! he has almost cracked my head.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: O the monster! For shame, Tony. You a man, and behave so!

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: If I'm a man, let me have my fortin. Ecod! I'll not be made a fool of no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P:
Is this, ungrateful boy, all that I'm to get for the pains I have taken in your education? I that have rock'd yon in your cradle, and fed that pretty mouth with a spoon! Did not I work that waist∣coat to make you genteel? Did not I prescribe for
you every day, and weep while the receipt was oper∣ating?

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Ecod! you had reason to weep, for you have been dosing me ever since I was born. I have gone through every receipt in the complete housewife ten times over; and you have thoughts of coursing me through Quincy next spring. But, ecod! I tell you, I'll not be made a fool of no longer.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Wasn't it all for your good, viper? Wasn't it all for your good?

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: I wish you'd let me and my good alone then. Snubbing this way when I'm in spirits. If I'm to have any good, let it come of itself; not to keep dinging it, dinging it into one so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: That's false; I never see you when you're in spi∣rits. No, Tony, you then go to the alehouse or kennel. I'm never to be delighted with your agree∣able, wild notes, unfeeling monster!

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Ecod! mamma, your own notes are the wildest of the two.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Was ever the like? But I see he wants to break my heart, I see he does.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Dear madam, permit me to lecture the young gentleman a little. I'm certain I can persuade him to his duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Well! I must retire. Come, Constance, my love. You see, Mr. Hastings, the wretchedness of my situation: was ever poor woman so plagued with a dear, sweet, pretty, provoking, undutiful boy.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY, singing.
SP.P: "There was a young man riding by, and fain would have his will. Rang do didlo dee."—Don't mind her. Let her cry. It's the comfort of her heart. I have seen her and sister cry over a book for an hour together, and they said, they liked the book the better the more it made them cry.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Then you're no friend to the ladies, I find, my pretty young gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: That's as I find 'um.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Not to her of your mother's chusing, I dare an∣swer? And yet she appears to me a pretty well-tem∣pered girl.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: That's because you don't know her as well as I. Ecod! I know every inch about her; and there's not a more bitter cantanckerous toad in all christen∣dom.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: (Aside) Pretty encouragement this for a lover!

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: I have seen her since the height of that. She has as many tricks as a hare in a thicket, or a colt the first day's breaking.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: To me she appears sensible and silent!

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Aye, before company. But when she's with her play-mate she's as loud as a hog in a gate.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: But there is a meek modesty about her that charms me.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Yes, but curb her never so little, she kicks up, and you're flung in a ditch.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Well, but you must allow her a little beauty.—Yes, you must allow her some beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P:
Bandbox! She's all a made up thing, mum. Ah! could you but see Bet Bouncer of these parts,
you might then talk of beauty. Ecod, she has two eyes as black as stoes, and cheeks as broad and red as a pulpit cushion. She'd make two of she.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Well, what say you to a friend that would take this bitter bargain off your hands?

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Anon.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Would you thank him that would take Miss Ne∣ville, and leave you to happiness and your dear Betsy?

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Aye; but where is there such a friend, for who would take her?

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: I am he. If you but assist me, I'll engage to whip her off to France, and you shall never hear more of her.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Assist you! Ecod I will, to the last drop of my blood. I'll clap a pair of horses to your chaise that shall trundle you off in a twinkling, and may be get you a part of her fortin beside, in jewels, that you little dream of.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: My dear 'squire, this looks like a lad of spirit.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Come along then, and you shall see more of my spirit before you have done with me.
Singing.
We are the boys
That fears no noise
Where the thundering cannons roar.

DIV1.HEAD: ACT THE THIRD.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: WHAT could my old friend Sir Charles mean by recommending his son as the modestest young man in town? To me he appears the most impu∣dent piece of brass that ever spoke with a tongue. He has taken possession of the easy chair by the fire∣side already. He took off his boots in the parlour, and desired me to see them taken care of. I'm de∣sirous to know how his impudence affects my daugh∣ter.—She will certainly be shocked at it.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Well, my Kate, I see you have changed your dress as I bid you; and yet, I believe, there was no great occasion.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I find such a pleasure, Sir, in obeying your com∣mands, that I take care to observe them without ever debating their propriety.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: And yet, Kate, I sometimes give you some cause, particularly when I recommended my modest gen∣tleman to you as a lover to-day.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: You taught me to expect something extraordinary, and I find the original exceeds the description.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I was never so surprised in my life! He has quite confounded all my faculties!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I never saw any thing like it: and a man of the world too!

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Aye, he learned it all abroad,—what a fool was I, to think a young man could learn modesty by tra∣velling. He might as soon learn wit at a masque∣rade.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: It seems all natural to him.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: A good deal assisted by bad company and a French dancing-master.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Sure you mistake, papa! A French dancing∣master could never have taught him that timid look,—that aukward address,—that bashful manner—

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Whose look? whose manner, child?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Mr. Marlow's: his mauvaise honte, his timidity struck me at the first sight.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Then your first sight deceived you; for I think him one of the most brazen first sights that ever astonished my senses.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Sure, Sir, you rally! I never saw any one so mo∣dest.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: And can you be serious! I never saw such a bouncing swaggering puppy since I was born. Bul∣ly Dawson was but a fool to him.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Surprising! He met me with a respectful bow, a stammering voice, and a look fixed on the ground.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: He met me with a loud voice, a lordly air, and a familiarity that made my blood freeze again.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: He treated me with diffidence and respect; cen∣sured the manners of the age; admired the pru∣dence of girls that never laughed; tired me with apologies for being tiresome; then left the room with a bow, and, "madam, I would not for the world detain you."

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P:
He spoke to me as if he knew me all his life be∣fore. Asked twenty questions, and never, waited
for an answer, interrupted my best remarks with some, silly pun, and when I was in my best story of the Duke of Marlborough and Prince Eugene, he asked if I had not a good hand at making punch. Yes, Kate, he asked your father if he was a maker of punch.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: One of us must certainly be mistaken.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: If he be what he he has shewn himself, I'm de∣termined he shall never have my consent.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: And if he be the fullen thing I take him, he shall never have mine.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: In one thing then we are agreed—to reject him.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Yes. But upon conditions. For if you should find him less impudent, and I more presuming; if you find him more respectful, and I more importu∣nate—I don't know—the fellow is well enough for a man—Certainly we don't meet many such at a horse race in the country.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: If we should find him so—But that's impossible. The first appearance has done my business. I'm seldom deceived in that.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: And yet there may be many good qualities under that first appearance.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Aye, when a girl finds a fellow's outside to her taste, she then sets about guessing the rest of his fur∣niture. With her, a smooth face stands for good sense, and a genteel figure for every virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I hope, Sir, a conversation begun with a compli∣ment to my good sense won't end with a sneer at my understanding?

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Pardon me, Kate. But if young Mr. Brazen can find the art of reconciling contradictions, he may please us both, perhaps.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: And as one of us must be mistaken, what if we go to make further discoveries?

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Agreed. But depend on't I'm in the right.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: And depend on't I'm not much in the wrong.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter TONY, running in with a casket.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Ecod! I have got them. Here they are. My cousin Con's necklaces, bobs and all. My mother shan't cheat the poor souls out of their fortin neither. O! my genus, is that you?

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: My dear friend, how have you managed with your mother? I hope you have amused her with pre∣tending love for your cousin, and that you are wil∣ling to be reconciled at last? Our horses will be re∣freshed in a short time, and we shall soon be ready to set off.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: And here's something to bear your charges by the way, (giving the casket) your sweetheart's jewels. Keep them, and hang those, I say, that would rob you of one of them.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: But how have you procured them from your mo∣ther?

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Ask me no questions, and I'll tell you no fibs. I procured them by the rule of thumb. If I had not a key to every drawer in mother's bureau, how could I go to the alehouse so often as I do? An ho∣nest man may rob himself of his own at any time.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Thousands do it every day. But to be plain with you, Miss Neville is endeavouring to procure them from her aunt this very instant. If she succeeds, it will be the most delicate way at least of obtaining them.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Well, keep them, till you know how it will be. But I know how it will be well enough, she'd as soon part with the only sound, tooth in her head.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: But I dread the effects of her resentment, when she finds she has lost them.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Never you mind her resentment, leave me to ma∣nage that. I don't value her resentment the bounce of a cracker. Zounds! here they are. Morrice! Prance!

DIV1.STAGE: TONY, Mrs. HARDCASTLE, and Miss NEVILLE.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Indeed, Constance, you amaze me. Such a girl as you want jewels? It will be time enough for jewels, my dear, twenty years hence, when your beauty begins to want repairs.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: But what will repair beauty at forty, will certain∣ly improve it at twenty, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P:
Yours, my dear, can admit of none. That natu∣ral blush is beyond a thousand ornaments. Besides, child, jewels are quite out at present. Don't you see half the ladies of our acquaintance, my lady Kill-day-light, and Mrs. Crump, and the rest of
them, carry their jewels to town, and bring nothing but paste and marcasites back.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: But who knows, madam, but somebody that shall be nameless would like me best with all my little finery about me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Consult your glass, my dear, and then see if, with such a pair of eyes, you want any better sparklers. What do you think, Tony, my dear? does your cousin Con, want any jewels, in your eyes, to set off her beauty?

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: That's as thereafter may be.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: My dear aunt, if you knew how it would oblige me.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: A parcel of old-fashioned rose and table cut things. They would make you look like the court of king Solomon at a puppet-shew. Besides, I be∣lieve I can't readily come at them. They may be missing for aught I know to the contrary.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: (Apart to Mrs. Hardcastle.) Then why don't you tell her so at once, as she's so longing for them? Tell her they're lost. It's the only way to quiet her. Say they're lost, and call me to bear witness.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (Apart to Tony.) You know, my dear, I'm only keeping them for you. So if I say they're gone, you'll bear me witness, will you? He! he! he!

SP.SPEAKER: Tony.
SP.P: Never sear me. Ecod! I'll say I saw them taken out with my own eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: I desire them but for a day, madam. Just to be permitted to shew them as relics, and then they may be lock'd up again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: To be plain with you, my dear Constance; if I could find them, you should have them. They're missing, I assure you. Lost, for aught I know; but we must have patience wherever they are.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: I'll not believe it; this is but a shallow pretence to deny me. I know they're too valuable to be so slightly kept, and as you are to answer for the loss.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Don't be alarm'd, Constance. If they be lost, I must restore an equivalent. But my son knows they are missing, and not to be found.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: That I can bear witness to. They are missing, and not to be found, I'll take my oath on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: You must learn resignation, my dear; for though we lose our fortune, yet we should not lose our pa∣tience. See me, how calm I am.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: Aye, people are generally calm at the misfortunes of others.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Now, I wonder a girl of your good sense should waste a thought upon such trumpery. We shall soon find them; and, in the mean time, you shall make use of my garnets till your jewels be found.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: I detest garnets.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: The most becoming things in the world to set off a clear complexion. You have often seen how well they look upon me, You shall have them.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: I dislike them of all things. You shan't stir.—Was ever any thing so provoking to mislay my own jewels, and force me to wear her trumpery.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Don't be a fool. If she gives you the garnets, take what you can get. The jewels are your own already. I have stolen them out of her bureau, and she does not know it. Fly to your spark, he'll tell you more of the matter. Leave me to manage her.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: My dear cousin!

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Vanish. She's here, and has missed them alrea∣dy. Zounds! how she fidgets and spits about like a catharine wheel.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Confusion! thieves! robbers! we are cheated, plundered, broke open, undone.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: What's the matter, what's the matter, mamma? I hope nothing has happened to any of the good fa∣mily!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: We are robbed. My bureau has been broke open, the jewels taken out, and I'm undone.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Oh! is that all? Ha! ha! ha! By the laws, I never saw it better acted in my life. Ecod, I thought you was ruin'd in earnest, ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Why, boy, I'm ruin'd in earnest. My bureau has been broke open, and all taken away.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Stick to that; ha! ha! ha! stick to that. I'll bear witness, you know, call me to bear witness.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I tell you, Tony, by all that's precious, the jewels are gone, and I shall be ruin'd for ever.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Sure I know they're gone, and I'm to say so.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: My dearest Tony, but hear me. They're gone, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: By the laws, mamma, you make me for to laugh, ha! ha! I know who took them, well enough, ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Was there ever such a blockhead, that can't tell the difference between jest and earnest! I tell you I'm not in jest, booby.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: That's right, that's right: you must be in a bit∣ter passion, and then nobody will suspect either of us. I'll bear witness that they are gone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Was there ever such a cross-grain'd brute, that won't hear me? Can you bear witness that you're no better than a fool? Was ever poor woman so beset with fools on one hand, and thieves on the other.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: I can bear witness to that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Bear witness again, you blockhead you, and I'll turn you out of the room directly. My poor niece, what will become of her! Do you laugh, you un∣feeling brute, as if you enjoyed my distress?

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: I can bear witness to that.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Do you insult me, monster? I'll teach you to vex your mother, I will.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: I can bear witness to that.
He runs off, she follows him.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: What an unaccountable creature is that brother of mine, to send them to the house as an inn, ha! ha! I don't wonder at his impudence.

SP.SPEAKER: MAID.
SP.P: But what is more, madam, the young gentleman, as you passed by in your present dress, ask'd me if you were the bar-maid? He mistook you for the bar-maid, madam.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Did he? Then as I live, I'm resolved to keep up the delusion. Tell me, Pimple, how do you like my present dress. Don't you think I look some∣thing like Cherry in the Beaux Stratagem?

SP.SPEAKER: MAID.
SP.P: It's the dress, madam, that every lady wears is the country, but when she visits, or receives com∣pany.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: And are you sure he does not remember my face or person?

SP.SPEAKER: MAID.
SP.P: Certain of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I vow, I thought so? for though we spoke for some time together, yet his fears were such, that he never once looked up during the interview. Indeed, if he had, my bonnet would have kept him from seeing me.

SP.SPEAKER: MAID.
SP.P: But what do you hope from keeping him in his mistake?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: In the first place, I shall be seen, and that is no small advantage to a girl who brings her face to market. Then I shall perhaps make an acquaint∣ance, and that's no small victory gained over one who never addresses any but the wildest of her sex. But my chief aim is to take my gentleman off his guard, and, like an invisible champion of romance, examine the giant's force before I offer to combat.

SP.SPEAKER: MAID.
SP.P: But are you sure you can act your part, and dis∣guise your voice, so that he may mistake that, as he has already mistaken your person?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P:
Never fear me. I think I have got the true bar∣cant.—Did your honour call?—Attend the Lion
there.—Pipes and tobacco for the Angel.—The Lamb has been outrageous this half hour.

SP.SPEAKER: MAID.
SP.P: It will do, madam. But he's here.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: What a bawling in every part of the house! I have scarce a moment's repose. If I go to the best room, there I find my host and his story. If I fly to the gallery, there we have my hostess with her courtesy down to the ground. I have at last got a moment to myself, and now for recollection. [Walks and muses.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Did you call, Sir? Did your honour call?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (Musing.) As for Miss Hardcastle, she's too grave and sentimental for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Did your honour call?
She still places herself before him, be turning away.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: No, child, (musing.) Besides, from the glimpse I had of her, I think she squints.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I'm sure, Sir, I heard the bell ring.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: No, no. (musing.) I have pleased my father, however, by coming down, and I'll to-morrow please myself by returning.
Taking out his tablets, and perusing.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Perhaps the other gentleman called, Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: MARIOW.
SP.P: I tell you, no.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I should be glad to know, Sir. We have such a parcel of servants.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: No, no, I tell you. (Looks full in her face). Yes, child, I think I did call. I wanted—I wanted—I vow, child, you are vastly handsome.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: O la, Sir, you'll make one asham'd.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Never saw a more sprightly malicious eye. Yes, yes, my dear, I did call. Have you got any of your—a—what d'ye call it in the house?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: No, Sir, we have been out of that these ten days.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: One may call in this house, I find, to very little purpose. Suppose I should call for a taste, just by way of trial, of the nectar of your lips; perhaps I might be disappointed in that too.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Nectar! nectar! That's a liquor there's no call for in those parts. French, I suppose. We keep no French wines here, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Of true English growth, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Then it's odd I should not know it. We brew all sorts of wines in this house, and I have lived here these eighteen years.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Eighteen years! Why one would think, child, you kept the bar before you were born. How old are you?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: O! Sir, I must not tell my age. They say wo∣men and music should never be dated.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: To guess at this distance you can't be much above forty (approaching). Yet nearer I don't think so much (approaching). By coming close to some wo∣men they look younger still; but when we come very close indeed— (attempting to kiss her).

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Pray, Sir, keep your distance. One would think you wanted to know one's age as they do horses, by mark of mouth.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: I protest, child, you use me extremely ill. If you keep me at this distance, how is it possible you and I can ever be acquainted?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: And who wants to be acquainted with you? I want no such acquaintance, not I. I'm sure you did not treat Miss Hardcastle that was here awhile ago in this obstropalous manner. I'll warrant me, before her you look'd dash'd, and kept bowing to the ground, and talk'd, for all the word, as if you was before a justice of peace.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (Aside) Egad! She has hit it, sure enough. (To her) In awe of her, child s Ha! ha! ha! A mere, aukward, squinting thing, no, no. I find you don't know me. I laugh'd, and rallied her a little; but I was unwilling to be too severe. No, I could not be too severe, curse me!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: O! then, Sir, you are a favourite, I find, among the ladies?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P:
Yes, my dear, a great favourite. And yet, hang me, I don't see what they find in me to follow. At the ladies club in town, I'm called their agreeable Rattle. Rattle, child, is not my real name, but one I'm known by. My name is Solomons. Mr.
Solomons, my dear, at your service. (Offering to sa∣lute her.)

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Hold, Sir; you are introducing me to your club, not to yourself. And you're so great a favourite there, you say?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Yes, my dear. There's Mrs. Mantrap, lady Bet∣ty Blackleg, the countess of Sligo, Mrs. Langhorns, old Miss Biddy Buckskin, and your humble servant, keep up the spirit of the place.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Then it's a very merry place, I suppose?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Yes, as merry as cards, supper, wine, and old wo∣men, can make us.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: And their agreeable Rattle, ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (Aside) Egad! I don't quite like this chit. She looks knowing, methinks. You laugh, child!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I can't but laugh to think what time they all have for minding their work or their family.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (Aside) All's well; she don't laugh at me. (To her) Do you ever work, child?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Aye, sure. There's not a screen or a quilt in the whole house but what can bear witness to that.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Odso! then you must shew me your embroidery. I embroider and draw patterns myself a little. If you want a judge of your work you must apply to me. [Seizing her hand.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Aye, but the colours do not look well by candle∣light. You shall see all in the morning.
Struggling.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: And why not now, my angel? Such beauty fires beyond the power of resistance—Pshaw! the fa∣ther here! My old luck: I never nick'd seven that I did not throw ames ace three times following.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter HARDCASTLE, who stands in surprize.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: So, madam. So I find this is your modest lover. This is your humble admirer that kept his eyes fix∣ed on the ground, and only ador'd at humble dis∣tance. Kate, Kate, art thou not asham'd to deceive your father so?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Never trust me, dear papa, but he's still the mo∣dest man I first took him for, you'll be convinc'd of it as well as I.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: By the hand of my body I believe his impudence is infectious! Didn't I see him seize your hand? Didn't I see him hawl you about like a milk-maid? and now you talk of his respect and his modesty, forsooth!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: But if I shortly convince you of his modesty, that he has only the faults that will pass off with time, and the virtues that will improve with age, I hope you'll forgive him.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: The girl would actually make one run mad! I tell you I'll not be convinced. I am convinced. He has scarce been three hours in the house, and he has already encroached on all my prerogatives. You may like his impudence, and call it modesty. But my son-in-law, madam, must have very differ∣ent qualifications.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Sir, I ask but this night to convince you.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: You shall not have half the time, for I have thoughts of turning him out this very hour.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Give me that hour then, and I hope to satisfy you.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Well, an hour let it be then. But I'll have no trifling with your father. All fair and open, do you mind me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I hope, Sir, you have ever found that I consider∣ed your commands as my pride; for your kindness is such, that my duty as yet has been inclination.

DIV1.HEAD: ACT THE FOURTH.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: YOU surprise me! Sir Charles Marlow expected here this night? Where have you had your infor∣mation?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: You may depend upon it. I just saw his letter to Mr. Hardcastle, in which he tells him he intends setting out a few hours after his son.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Then, my Constance, all must be compleated be∣fore he arrives. He knows me; and should he find me here, would discover my name, and perhaps my designs, to the rest of the family.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: The jewels, I hope, are safe.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P:
Yes, yes. I have sent them to Marlow, who keeps the keys of our baggage. In the mean time, I'll go to prepare matters for our elopement. I have had the, squire's promise of a fresh pair of horses;
and, if I should not see him again, will write him further directions.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: Well! success attend you. In the mean time, I'll go amuse my aunt with the old pretence of a violent passion for my cousin.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter MARLOW, followed by a servant.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: I wonder what Hastings could mean by sending me so valuable a thing as a casket to keep for him, when he knows the only place I have is the seat of a post∣coach at an inn-door. Have you deposited the casket with the landlady, as I ordered you? Have you put it into her own hands?

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Yes, your honour.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: She said she'd keep it safe, did she?

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Yes, she said she'd keep it safe enough; she ask'd me how I came by it? and she said she had a great mind to make me give an account of myself.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P:
Ha! ha! ha! They're safe however. What an unaccountable set of beings have we got amongst! This little bar-maid though runs in my head most strangely, and drives out the absurdities of all the
rest of the family. She's mine, she must be mine, or I'm greatly mistaken.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Bless me! I quite forgot to tell her that I intend∣ed to prepare at the bottom of the garden. Mar∣low here, and in spirits too!

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Give me joy, George! Crown me, shadow me with laurels! Well, George, after all, we modest fellows don't want for success among the women.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Some women you mean. But what success has your honour's modesty been crowned with now, that it grows so insolent upon us?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Didn't you see the tempting, brisk, lovely, little thing that runs about the house with a bunch of keys to its girdle?

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Well, and what then?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: She's mine, you rogue you. Such fire, such mo∣tion, such eyes, such lips—but, egad! she would not let me kiss them though.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: But are you so sure, so very sure of her?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Why, man, she talked of shewing me her work above stairs, and I am to improve the pattern.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: But how can you, Charles, go about to rob a wo∣man of her honour?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Pshaw! pshaw! We all know the honour of the bar-maid of an inn. I don't intend to rob her, take my word for it, there's nothing in this house, I shan't honestly pay for.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: I believe the girl has virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: And if she has, I should be the last man in the world that would attempt to corrupt it.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: You have taken care, I hope, of the casket I sent you to lock up? It's in safety?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Yes, yes. It's safe enough. I have taken care of it. But how could you think the seat of a post∣coach at an inn-door a place of safety? Ah! Numb∣skull! I have taken better precautions for you than you did for yourself.—I have—

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: What!

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: I have sent it to the landlady to keep for you.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: To the landlady!

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: The landlady!

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: You did?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: I did. She's to be answerable for its forth-com∣ing, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Yes, she'll bring it forth, with a witness.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Wasn't I right? I believe you'll allow that I act∣ed prudently upon this occasion?

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: (Aside) He must not see my uneasiness.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: You seem a little disconcerted though, methinks. Sure nothing has happened?

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: No, nothing. Never was in better spirits in all my life. And so you left it with the landlady, who, no doubt, very readily undertook the charge?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Rather too readily. For she nor only kept the casket; but, through her great precaution, was go∣ing to keep the messenger too. Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: He! he! he! They're safe however.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: As a guinea in a miser's purse.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: (Aside) So now all hopes of fortune are at an end, and we must set off without it. (To him) Well, Charles, I'll leave you to your meditations on the pretty bar-maid, and, he! he! he! may you be as successful for yourself as you have been for me.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Thank ye, George! I ask no more. Ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I no longer know my own house. It's turned all topsey-turvey. His servants have got drunk alrea∣dy. I'll bear it no longer, and yet, from my respect for his father, I'll be calm. (To him) Mr. Marlow, your servant. I'm your very humble servant.
Bowing low.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Sir, your humble servant. (Aside) What's to be the wonder now?

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I believe, Sir, you must be sensible, Sir, that no man alive ought to be more welcome than your fa∣ther's son, Sir. I hope you think so?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: I do from my soul, Sir. I don't want much in∣treaty. I generally make my father's son welcome wherever he goes.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I believe you do, from my soul, Sir. But though I say nothing to your own conduct, that of your ser∣vants is unsufferable. Their manner of drinking is setting a very bad example in this house, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: I protest, my very good Sir, that is no fault of mine. If they don't drink as they ought they are to blame. I ordered them not to spare the cellar. I did, I assure you. (To the side scene) Here, let one of my servants come up. (To him) My positive directions were, that as I did not drink myself, they should make up for my deficiencies below.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Then they had your orders for what they do! I'm satisfied!

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: They had, I assure you. You shall hear from one of themselves.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P:
You, Jeremy! Come forward, sirrah! What were my orders? Were you not told to drink freely,
and call for what you thought fit, for the good of the house?

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (Aside) I begin to lose my patience.

SP.SPEAKER: JEREMY.
SP.P: Please your honour, liberty and Fleet-street for ever! Though I'm but a servant, I'm as good as another man. I'll drink for no man before supper, Sir, dammy! Good liquor will sit upon a good supper, but a good supper will not sit upon—hiccup—upon my conscience, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: You see, my old friend, the fellow is as drunk as he can possibly be. I don't know what you'd have more; unless you'd have the poor devil soused in a beer-barrel.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Zounds! he'll drive me distracted if I contain myself any longer. Mr. Marlow. Sir; I have submitted to your insolence for more than four hours, and I see no likelihood of its coming to an end. I'm now resolved to be master here, Sir, and I de∣sire that you and your drunken pack may leave my house directly.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Leave your house!—Sure you jest, my good friend? What, when I'm doing what I can to please you.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I tell you, Sir, you don't please me; so I desire you'll leave my house.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Sure you cannot be serious? at this time o'night, and such a night. You only mean to banter me?

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I tell you, Sir, I'm serious? and, now that my passions are rouzed, I say this house is mine, Sir; this house is mine, and I command you to leave it directly.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! A puddle in a storm. I shan't stir a step, I assure you. (In a serious tone) This, your house, fellow! It's my house. This is my house. Mine, while I chuse to stay. What right have you to bid me to leave this house, Sir? I never met with such impudence, curse me, never in my whole life before.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P:
Nor I, confound me if ever I did. To come to my house, to call for what he likes, to turn me out of my own chair, to insult the family, to order his servants to get drunk, and then to tell me "This house is mine, Sir." By all that's impudent it makes me laugh. Ha! ha! ha! Pray, Sir, (ban∣tering) as you take the house, what think you of taking the rest of the furniture? There's a pair of silver candlesticks, and there's a fire-screen, and
here's a pair of brazen nosed bellows, perhaps you may take a fancy to them?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Bring me your bill, Sir; bring me your bill, and let's make no more words about it.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: There are a set of prints too. What think you of the rake's progress for your own apartment?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Bring me your bill, I say; and I'll leave you and your infernal house directly.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Then there's a mahogany table that you may see your own face in.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: My bill, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I had forgot the great chair, for your own parti∣cular slumbers, after a hearty meal.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Zounds! bring me my bill, I say, and let's hear no more on't.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Young man, young man, from your father's let∣ter to me, I was taught to expect a well-bred modest man, as a visitor here, but now I find him no better than a coxcomb and a bully; but he will be down here presently, and shall hear more of it.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: How's this! Sure I have not mistaken the house! Every thing looks like an inn. The servants cry, coming. The attendance is aukward; the bar-maid too to attend us. But she's here, and will further inform me. Whither so fast, child? A word with you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Let it be short then. I'm in a hurry. (Aside) I believe he begins to find out his mistake, but it's too soon quite to undeceive him.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Pray, child, answer me one question. What are you, and what may your business in this house be?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: A relation of the family, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: What, a poor relation?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Yes, Sir. A poor relation appointed to keep the keys, and to see that the guests want nothing in my power to give them.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: That is, you act as the bar-maid of this inn.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Inn. O law—What brought that in your head? One of the best families in the county keep an inn! Ha! ha! ha! old Mr. Hardcastle's house an inn!

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Mr. Hardcastle's house! Is this house Mr. Hard∣castle's house, child?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Aye, sure. Whose else should it be?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: So then all's out, and I have been damnably im∣posed on. O, confound my stupid head, I shall be laugh'd at over the whole town. I shall be stuck up in caricatura in all the print-shops. The Dullissimo Maccaroni. To mistake this house of all others for an inn, and my father's old friend for an inn-keeper! What a swaggering puppy must he take me for? What a silly puppy do I find myself? There again, may I be hanged, my dear, but I mistook you for the bar-maid.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Dear me! dear me! I'm sure there's nothing in my behaviour to put me upon a level with one of that stamp.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P:
Nothing, my dear, nothing. But I was in for a list of blunders, and could not help making you a subscriber. My stupidity saw every thing the wrong way. I mistook your affiduity for assurance, and
your simplicity for allurement. But its over—This house I no more shew my face in.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I hope, Sir, I have done nothing to disoblige you. I'm sure I should be sorry to affront any gentleman who has been so polite, and said so many civil things to me. I'm sure I should be sorry (pretending to cry) if he left the family upon my account. I'm sure I should be sorry, people said any thing amiss, since I have no fortune but my character.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (Aside) By Heaven, she weeps. This is the first mark of tenderness I ever had from a modest woman, and it touches me. (To her) Excuse me, my lovely girl, you are the only part of the family I leave with reluctance. But to be plain with you, the dif∣ference of our birth, fortune and education, make an honourable connection impossible: and I can never harbour a thought of seducing simplicity that trusted in my honour, of bringing ruin upon one, whose only fault was being too lovely.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (Aside) Generous man! I now begin to admire him. (To him) But I'm sure my family is as good as Miss Hardcastle's, and though I'm poor, that's no great misfortune to a contented mind, and, until this moment, I never thought that it was bad to want fortune.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: And why now, my pretty simplicity?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Because it puts me at a distance from one, that if I had a thousand pound I would give it all to.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (Aside) This simplicity bewitches me, so that if I stay I'm undone. I must make one bold effort, and leave her. (To her) Your partiality in my fa∣vour, my dear, touches me most sensibly, and were I to live for myself alone, I could easily fix my choice. But I owe too much to the opinion of the world, too much to the authority of a father, so that—I can scarcely speak it—it affects me. Fare∣wel.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I never knew half his merit till now. He shall not go, if I have power or art to detain him. I'll still preserve the character in which I stoop'd to con∣quer, but will undeceive my papa, who, perhaps, may laugh him out of his resolution.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Aye, you may steal for yourselves the next time. I have done my duty. She has got the jewels again, that's a sure thing; but she believes it was all a mistake of the servants.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: But, my dear cousin, sure you won't forsake us in this distress. If she in the least suspects that I am going off, I shall certainly be locked up, or sent to my aunt Pedigree's, which is ten times worse.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: To be sure, aunts of all kinds are damn'd bad things. But what can I do? I have got you a pair of horses that will fly like Whistlejacket, and I'm sure you can't say but I have courted you nicely be∣fore her face. Here she comes, we must court a bit Or two more, for fear she should suspect us.
They retire, and seem to fondle.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Well, I was greatly fluttered, to be sure. But my son tells me it was all a mistake of the servants. I shan't be easy, however, till they are fairly mar∣ried, and then let her keep her own fortune. But what do I see! fondling together, as I'm alive. I never saw Tony so sprightly before. Ah! have I caught you, my pretty doves! What, billing, ex∣changing stolen glances, and broken murmurs. Ah!

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: As for murmurs, mother, we grumble a little now and then, to be sure. But there's no love lost be∣tween us.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
