SP.P: A mere sprinkling, Tony, upon the flame, only to make it burn brighter.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: Cousin Tony promises to give us more of his com∣pany at home. Indeed, he shan't leave us any more. It won't leave us, cousin Tony, will it?

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: O! it's a pretty creature. No, I'd sooner leave my horse in a pound, than leave you when you smile upon one so. Your laugh makes you so be∣coming.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: Agreeable cousin! Who can help admiring that natural humour, that pleasant, broad, red, thought∣less, (patting his cheek) ah! it's a bold face.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Pretty innocence!

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: I'm sure I always lov'd cousin Con's hazle eyes, and her pretty long fingers, that she twists this way and that, over the haspicholls, like a parcel of bob∣bins.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P:
Ah, he would charm the bird from the tree. I was never so happy before. My boy takes after his father, poor Mr. Lumpkin, exactly. The jewels, my dear Con, shall be yours incontinently. You shall have them. Isn't he a sweet boy, my dear?
You shall be married to-morrow, and we'll put off' the rest of his education, like Dr. Drowsy's sermons, to a fitter opportunity.

SP.SPEAKER: DIGGORY.
SP.P: Where's the 'squire? I have got a letter for your worship.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Give it to my mamma. She reads all my letters first.

SP.SPEAKER: DIGGORY.
SP.P: I had orders to deliver it into your own hands.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Who does it come from?

SP.SPEAKER: DIGGORY.
SP.P: Your worship mun ask that o' the letter itself.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: I could wish to know, though (turning the letter, and gazing on it.)

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: (Aside) Undone! undone! A letter to him from Hastings. I know the hand. If my aunt sees it we are ruined for ever. I'll keep her employ'd a little if I can. (To Mrs. Hardcastle) But I have not told yon, madam, of my cousin's smart answer just now to Mr. Marlow. We so laugh'd—You must know, madam,—This way a little, for he must not hear us.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: (Still gazing) A damn'd cramp piece of penman∣ship, as ever I saw in my life. I can read your print hand very well. But here there are such han∣dles, and shanks, and dashes, that one can scarce tell the head from the tail. "To Anthony Lump∣kin, esquire." It's very odd, I can read the out∣side of my letters, where my own name is, well enough. But when I come to open it, it's all—buzz. That's hard, very hard; for the inside of the letter is always the cream of the correspon∣dence.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! Very well, very well. And so my son was too hard for the philosopher.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: Yes, madam; but you must hear the rest, madam. A little more this way, or he may hear us. You'll hear how he puzzled him again.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: He seems strangely puzzled now himself, me∣thinks.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: (Still gazing) A damn'd up and down hand, as if it was disguised in liquor. (Reading) Dear Sir. Aye, that's that. Then there's an M, and a T, and an S, but whether the next be an izzard or an R, confound me, I cannot tell.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: What's that, my dear. Can I give you any as∣sistance?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: Pray, aunt, let me read it. No body reads a cramp hand better than I. (twitching the letter from her) Do you know who it is from?

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Can't tell, except from Dick Ginger the feeder.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: Aye, so it is, (pretending to read) Dear 'squire, hoping that you're in health, as I am at this present. The gentlemen of the Shake-bag club has cut the gentlemen of Goose-green quite out of feather. The odds—um—odd battle—um—long fight∣ing—um—here, here, it's all about cocks and fight∣ing; it's of no consequence, here, put it up, put it up. [Thrusting the crumpled letter upon him.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: But I tell you, miss, it's of all the consequence in the world. I would not lose the rest of it for a gui∣nea. Here, mother, do you make it out. Of no consequence! [Giving Mrs. Hardcastle the letter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P:
How's this! (reads) "Dear 'squire, I'm now waiting for Miss Neville, with a post-chaise and pair, at the bottom of the garden, but I find my horses yet unable to perform the journey. I ex∣pect you'll assist us with a pair of fresh horses, as
you promised. Dispatch is necessary, as the hag (aye the hag) your mother, will otherwise suspect us. Yours, Hastings." Grant me patience. I shall run distracted. My rage choaks me.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (Curtesying very low.) Fine spoken, madam, you are most miraculously polite and engaging, and quite the very pink of curtesy and circumspection, madam. (Changing her tone) And you, you great ill-fashioned oaf, with scarce sense enough to keep your mouth shut. Were you too join'd against me? But I'll defeat all your plots in a moment. As for you, madam, since you have got a pair of fresh horses ready, it would be cruel to disappoint them. So, if you please, instead of running away with your spark, prepare, this very moment, to run off with me. Your old aunt Pedigree will keep you secure, I'll warrant me. You too, Sir, may mount your horse, and guard us upon the way. Here, Thomas, Roger, Diggory, I'll shew you, that I wish you better than you do yourselves.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: So now I'm completely ruined.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Aye, that's a sure thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: What better could be expected from being con∣nected with such a stupid fool, and after all the nods and signs I made him?

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: By the laws, Miss, it was your own cleverness, and not my stupidity, that did your business. You were so nice and so busy with your Shake-bags and Goose∣greens, that I thought you could never be making believe.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: So, Sir, I find by my servant, that you have shewn my letter, and betray'd us. Was this well done, young gentleman?

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Here's another. Ask Miss there who betray'd you? Ecod, it was her doing, not mine.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: So I have been finely used here among you. Ren∣dered contemptible, driven into ill manners, despis∣ed, insulted, laughed at.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Here's another. We shall have old Bedlam broke loose presently.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: And there, Sir, is the gentleman to whom we all owe every obligation.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: What can I say to him, a mere boy, an idiot, whose ignorance and age are a protection.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: A poor contemptible booby, that would but dis∣grace correction.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: Yet with cunning and malice enough to make himself merry with all our embarrassments.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: An insensible cub.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Replete with tricks and mischief.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Baw! damme, but I'll fight you both one after the other,—with baskets.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: As for him, he's below resentment. But your conduct, Mr. Hastings, requires an explanation. You knew of my mistakes, yet would not undeceive me.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Tortured as I am with my own disappointments, is this a time for explanations. It is not friendly, Mr. Marlow.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: But, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: Mr. Marlow, we never kept on your mistake, till it was too late to undeceive you. Be pacified.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: My mistress desires you'll get ready immediately, madam. The horses are putting to. Your hat and things are in the next room. We are to go thirty miles before morning.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: Well, well; I'll come presently.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (To Hastings) Was it well done, Sir, to assist in rendering me ridiculous. To hang me out for the scorn of all my acquaintance. Depend upon it, Sir, I shall expect an explanation.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Was it well done, Sir, if you're upon that subject, to deliver what I entrusted to yourself, to the care of another, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: Mr. Hastings. Mr. Marlow. Why will you in∣crease my distress by this groundless dispute? I im∣plore, I intreat you—

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Your cloak, madam. My mistress is impatient.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: I come. Pray be pacified. If I leave you thus, I shall die with apprehension.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Your fan, muff, and gloves, madam. The horses are waiting.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: O, Mr. Marlow! if you knew what a scene of con∣straint and ill-nature lies before me, I'm sure it would convert your resentment into pity.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: I'm so distracted with a variety of passions, that I don't know what I do. Forgive me, madam. George, forgive me. You know my hasty temper, and should not exasperate it.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: The torture of my situation is my only excuse.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: Well, my dear Hastings, if you have that esteem for me that I think, that I am sure you have, your constancy for three years will but encrease the hap∣piness of our future connexion. If—

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (Within) Miss Neville. Constance, why Con∣stance, I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: I'm coming. Well, constancy. Remember, con∣stancy is the word.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: My heart! how can I support this. To be so near happiness, and such happiness!

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (To Tony) You see now, young gentleman, the effects of your folly. What might be amusement to you, is here disappointment, and even distress.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: (From a reverie) Ecod, I have hit it. It's here. Your hands. Yours and yours, my poor Sulky. My boots there, ho. Meet me two hours hence at the bottom of the garden; and if you don't find Tony Lumpkin a more good-natur'd fellow than you thought for, I'll give you leave to take my best horse, and Bet Bouncer into the bargain. Come along. My boots, ho!

DIV1.HEAD: ACT THE FIFTH.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: YOU saw the old lady and Miss Neville drive off, you say.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Yes, your honour. They went off in a post coach, and the young 'squire went on horseback. They're thirty miles off by this time.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Then all my hopes are over.

SP.SPEAKER: SERVANT.
SP.P: Yes, Sir. Old Sir Charles is arrived. He and the old gentleman of the house have been laughing at Mr. Marlow's mistake this half hour. They are coming this way.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Then I must not be seen. So now to my fruit∣less appointment at the bottom of the garden. This is about the time.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! The peremptory tone in which be sent forth his sublime commands.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: And the reserve with which I suppose he treated all your advances.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: And yet he might have seen something in me above a common inn-keeper, too.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Yes, Dick, but he mistook you for an uncommon inn-keeper, ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Well, I'm in too good spirits to think of any thing but joy. Yes, my dear friend, this union of our families will make our personal friendships heredi∣tary; and though my daughter's fortune is but small—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Why, Dick, will you talk of fortune to me? My son is possessed of more than a competence already, and can want nothing but a good and virtuous girl to share his happiness and encrease it. If they like each other, as you say they do—

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: If, man! I tell you they do like each other. My daughter as good as told me so.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: But girls are apt to flatter themselves, you know.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I saw him grasp her hand in the warmest manner myself; and here he comes to put you out of your ifs, I warrant him.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: I come, Sir, once more, to ask pardon for my strange conduct. I can scarce reflect on my inso∣lence without confusion.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Tut, boy, a trifle. You take it too gravely. An hour or two's laughing with my daughter will set all to rights again. She'll never like you the worse for it.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Sir, I shall be always proud of her approbation.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
MARLOW.
SP.P: Really, Sir, I have not that happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Come, boy, I'm an old fellow, and know what's what, as well as you that are younger. I know what has past between you; but mum.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Sure, Sir, nothing has past between us but the most profound respect on my side, and the most dis∣tant reserve on hers. You don't think, Sir, that my impudence has been past upon all the rest of the family.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Impudence! No, I don't say that—not quite im∣prudence—though girls like to be play'd with, and rumpled a little too sometimes. But she has told no tales, I assure you.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: I never gave her the slightest cause.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Well, well, I like modesty in its place well enough. But this is over-acting, young gentleman. You may be open. Your father and I will like you the better for it.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: May I die, Sir, if I ever—

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I tell you, she don't dislike you; and as I'm sure you like her—

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Dear, Sir—I protest,Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I see no reason why you should not be joined as fast as the parson can tie you.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: But hear me, Sir—

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Your father approves the match, I admire it, every moment's delay will be doing mischief, so—

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: But why won't you hear me? By all that's just and true, I never gave Miss Hardcastle the slightest mark of my attachment, or even the most distant hint to suspect me of affection. We had but one interview, and that was formal, modest and unin∣teresting.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (Aside) This fellow's formal modest impudence is beyond bearing.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: And you never grasp'd her hand, or made any protestations.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: As Heaven is my witness, I came down in obedi∣ence to your commands. I saw the lady without emotion, and parted without reluctance. I hope you'll exact no further proofs of my duty, nor pre∣vent me from leaving a house in which I suffer so many mortifications.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: I'm astonished at the air of sincerity with which he parted.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: And I'm astonish'd at the deliberate intrepidity of his assurance.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: I dare pledge my life and honour upon his truth.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Here comes my daughter, and I would stake my happiness upon her veracity.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Kate, come hither, child. Answer us sincerely, and without reserve; has Mr. Marlow made you any professions of love and affection?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: The question is very abrupt, Sir! But since you require unreserved sincerity, I think he has.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (To Sir Charles) You see.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: And pray, madam, have you and my son had more than one interview?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, several.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (To Sir Charles) You see.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: But did he profess any attachment?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: A lasting one.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Did he talk of love?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Much, Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Amazing! And all this formally?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Formally.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Now, my friend, I hope you are satisfied.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: And how did he behave, madam?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: As most profest admirers do. Said some civil things of my face, talked much of his want of me∣rit, and the greatness of mine; mentioned his heart, gave a short tragedy speech, and ended with pre∣tended rapture.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P:
Now I'm perfectly convinced, indeed. I know his conversation among women to be modest and submissive. This forward canting ranting manner
by no means describes him, and, I am confident, he never sate for the picture.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Then what, Sir, if I should convince you to your face of my sincerity? If you and my papa, in about half an hour, will place yourselves behind that screen, you shall hear him declare his passion to me in person.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Agreed. And if I find him what you describe, all my happiness in him must have an end.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: And if you don't find him what I describe—I fear my happiness must never have a beginning.

DIV1.STAGE: SCENE changes to the Back of the Garden.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: What an idiot am I, to wait here for a fellow, who probably takes a delight in mortifying me. He never intended to be punctual, and I'll wait no longer. What do I see! It is he! and perhaps with news of my Constance.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: My honest 'squire! I now find you a man of your word. This looks like friendship.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Aye, I'm your friend, and the best friend you have in the world, if you knew but all. This rid∣ing by night, by the bye, is cursedly tiresome. It has shook me worse than the basket of a stage∣coach.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: But how? where did you leave your fellow tra∣vellers? Are they in safety? Are they housed?

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Five and twenty miles in two hours and a half is no such bad driving. The poor beasts have smoak∣ed for it: rabbet me, but I'd rather ride forty miles after a fox, than ten with such varment.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Well, but where have you left the ladies? I die with impatience,

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Left them! Why where should I leave them, but where I found them?

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS,
SP.P: This is a riddle.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Riddle me this then. What's that goes round the house, and round the house, and never touches the house?

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS,
SP.P: I'm still astray.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Why that's it, mon. I have led them astray. By jingo, there's not a pond or slough within five miles of the place but they can tell the taste of.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Ha! ha! ha! I understand; you took them in a round, while they supposed themselves going for∣ward, and so you have at last brought them home again.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: You shall hear: I first took them down Feather∣bed-lane, where we stuck fast in the mud. I then rattled them crack over the stones of Up-and-down Hill—I then introduced them to the gibbet on Hea∣vy-tree Heath, and from that with a circumbendi∣bus, I fairly lodged them in the horse-pond at the bottom of the garden.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: But so accident, I hope.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: No, no. Only mother is confoundedly frighten∣ed. She thinks herself forty-miles off. She's sick of the journey, and the cattle can scarce crawl. So if your own horses be ready, you may whip off with coufin, and I'll be bound that no soul here can budge a foot to follow you.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: My dear friend, how can I be gratesul?

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Aye, now its dear friend, noble 'squire. Just now, it was all idiot, cub, and run me through the guts. Damn your way of fighting, I say. After we take a knock in this part of the country, we kiss and be friends. But if you had run me through the guts, then I should be dead, and you might go kiss the hangman.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: The rebuke is just. But I must hasten to relieve Miss Neville; if you keep the old lady employed, I promise to take care of the young one.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Never fear me. Here she comes. Vanish. She's got from the pond, and draggled up to the waist like a mermaid.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Oh, Tony, I'm killed. Shook. Battered to death. I shall never survive it. That last jolt that laid us against the quickset hedge has done my bu∣siness.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Alack, mamma, it was all your own fault. You would be for running away by night, without know∣ing one inch of the way.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I wish we were at home again. I never met so many accidents in so short a journey. Drench'd in the mud, overturned in a ditch, stuck fast in a slough, jolted to a jelly, and at last to lose our way. Whereabouts do you think we are, Tony?

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: By my guess we should come upon Crackskull common, about forty miles from home.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: O lud! O lud! The most notorious spot in all the country. We only want a robbery to make a complete night on't.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Don't be afraid, mamma, don't be afraid. Two of the five that kept here are hanged, and the other three may not find us. Don't be afraid. Is that a man that's galloping behind us? No; it's only a tree. Don't be afraid.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: The fright will certainly kill me.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Do you see any thing like a black hat moving be∣hind the thicket?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: O death!

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: No, it's only a cow. Don't be afraid, mamma; don't be afraid.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: As I'm alive, Tony, I see a man coming towards us. Ah! I'm sure on't. If he perceives us we are undone.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: (Aside) Father-in-law, by all that's unlucky, come to take one of his night walks. (To her) Ah, it's a highwayman, with pistols as long as my arm. A damn'd ill-looking fellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTIE.
SP.P: Good Heaven defend us! He approaches.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Do you hide yourself in that thicket, and leave me to manage him. If there be any danger I'll cough and cry hem. When I cough be sure to keep close.

DIV1.STAGE: [Mrs. Hardcastle hides behind a tree in the back scene.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I'm mistaken, or I heard voices of people in want of help. Oh, Tony, is that you? I did not ex∣pect you so soon back. Are your mother and her charge in safety?

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Very safe, Sir, at my aunt Pedigree's. Hem.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (From behind) Ah death! I find there's danger.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Forty miles in three hours; sure, that's too much, my youngster.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Stout horses and willing minds make short jour∣neys, as they say. Hem.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (From behind) Sure he'll do the dear boy no harm.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: But I heard a voice here; I should be glad to know from whence it came.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: It was I, Sir, talking to myself, Sir. I was say∣ing that forty miles in four hours was very good going. Hem. As to be sore it was. Hem. I have got a sort of cold by being out in the air. We'll go in, if you please. Hem.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: But if yon talk'd to yourself, you did not answer yourself. I am certain I heard two voices, and am resolved (raising his voice) to find the other out.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (From behind) Oh! he's coming to find me out. Oh!

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: What need yon go, Sir, if I tell you. Hem. I'll lay down my life for the truth—hem—I'll tell you all, Sir. [Detaining him.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I tell you, I will not be detained. I insist on see∣ing. It's in vain to expect I'll believe you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTIE.
SP.P: (Running forward from behind) O lud! he'll mur∣der my poor boy, ray darling. Here good gentle∣man, whet your rage upon me. Take my money, my life, but spare that young gentleman, spare my child, if you have any mercy.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: My wife! as I'm a Christian. From whence can she come? or what does she mean?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (Kneeling) Take compassion on us, good Mr. Highwayman. Take our money, our watches, all we have, but spare our lives. We will never bring you to justice, indeed we won't, good Mr. High∣wayman.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I believe the woman's out of her senses. What, Dorothy, don't you know me?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Mr. Hardcastle, as I'm alive! My fears blinded me. But who, my dear, could have expected to meet you here, in this frightful place, so far from home? What has brought you to follow us?

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P:
Sure, Dorothy, you have not lost your wits? So far from home, when you are within forty yards of
your own door. (To him) This is one of your old tricks, you graceless rogue you. (To her) Don't you know the gate, and the mulberry-tree; and don't you remember the horsepond, my dear?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Yes, I shall remember the horsepond as long as I live; I have caught ray death in it. (To Tony) And is it to you, you graceless varlet, I owe all this. I'll teach you to abuse your mother, I will.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Ecod, mother, all the parish says you have spoil'd me, and so you may take the fruits on' t.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I'll spoil you, I will.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: There's morality, however, in his reply.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: My dear Constance, why will you deliberate thus? If we delay a moment, all is lost for ever. Pluck up a little resolution, and we shall soon be out of the reach of her malignity.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: I find it impossible. My spirits are so sunk with the agitations I have suffered, that I am unable to face any new danger. Two or three years patience will at last crown us with happiness.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: Such a tedious delay is worse than inconstancy. Let us fly, my charmer. Let us date our happiness from this very moment. Perish fortune! Love and content will encrease what we possess beyond a mo∣narch's revenue. Let me prevail?

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: No, Mr. Hastings; no. Prudence once more comes to my relief, and I will obey its dictates. In the moment of passion, fortune may be despised, but it ever produces a lasting repentance. I'm resolved to apply to Mr. Hardcastle's compasion and justice for redress.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: But though he had the will, he has not the power to relieve you.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: But he has influence, and upon that I am resolv∣ed to rely.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: I have no hopes. But since you persist, I must re∣luctantly obey you.

SP.SPEAKER: SCENE changes.
SP.P: Enter Sir CHARLES and Miss HARDCASTLE.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P:
What a situation am I in! If what you say ap∣pears, I shall then find a guilty son. If what he
says be true, I shall then lose one, that, of all others, I most wish'd for a daughter.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I am proud of your approbation, and to shew I merit it, if you place yourselves as I directed, you shall hear his explicit declaration. But he comes.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: I'll to your father, and keep him to the appoint∣ment.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Though prepar'd for setting out, I come once more to take leave, nor did I, till this moment, know the pain I feel in the separation.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (In her own natural manner) I believe these suffer∣ings cannot be very great, Sir, which you can so ea∣sily remove. A day or two longer, perhaps, might lessen your uneasiness, by shewing the little value of what you now think proper to regret.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P:
(Aside) This girl every moment improves upon me. (To her) It must not be, madam. I have al∣ready trifled too long with my heart. My very pride begins to submit to my passion. The disparity of education and fortune, the anger of a parent, and the contempt of my equals, begin to lose their
weight; and nothing can restore me to myself, but this painsul effort of resolution.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Then go, Sir. I'll urge nothing more to detain you. Though my family be as good as hers you came down to visit, and my education, I hope, not inferior, what are these advantages without equal affluence? I must remain contented with the slight approbation of imputed merit; I must have only the mockery of your addresses, while all your serious aims are fixed on fortune.

DIV1.STAGE: Enter HARDCASTLE and Sir CHARLES from behind.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Here, behind this screen.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Aye, aye, make no noise. I'll engage my Kate covers him with confusion at last.

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P:
By Heavens, madam, fortune was ever my smallest consideration. Your beauty at first caught my eye; for who could see that without emotion. But every moment that I converse with you, steals in some new grace, heightens the picture, and gives it stronger expression. What at first seem'd rustic plainness, now appears resin'd simplicity. What
seem'd forward assurance, now strikes me as the re∣sult of courageous innocence, and conscious virtue.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: What can it mean? He amazes me!

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: I told you how it would be. Hush!

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: I am now determined to stay, madam, and I have too good an opinion of my father's discernment, when he sees you, to doubt his approbation.
Miss HARDCASTLE.

No, Mr. Marlow, I will not, cannot detain you. Do you think I could suffer a connexion, in which there is the smallest room for repentance? Do you think I would take the mean advantage of a tran∣sient passion, to load you with confusion? Do you think I could ever relish that happiness, which was acquired by lessening yours?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: By all that's good, I can have no happiness but what's in your power to grant me. Nor shall I ever feel repentance, but in not having seen your merits before. I will stay, even contrary to your wishes; and though you should persist to shun me, I will make my respectful assiduities atone for the levity of my past condust.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P:
Sir, I must entreat you'll desist. As our ac∣quaintance began, so let it end, in indifference. I
might have given an hour or two to levity; but se∣riously, Mr. Marlow, do you think I could ever sub∣mit to a connexion, where I must appear merce∣nary, and you imprudent? do you think I could ever catch at the confident addresses of a secure ad∣mirer?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: (Kneeling) Does this look like security? Does this look like confidence? No, madam, every mo∣ment that shews me your merit, only serves to en∣crease my diffidence and confusion. Here let me continue—

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: I can hold it no longer. Charles, Charles, how hast thou deceived me! Is this your indifference, your uninteresting conversation!

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Your cold contempt; your formal interview. What have you to say now?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: That I'm all amazement! What can it mean!

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: It means that you can say and unsay things at pleasure. That you can address a lady in private, and deny it in public; that you have one story for us, and another for my daughter!

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Daughter!—this lady your daughter!

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, my only daughter. My Kate, whose else should she be?

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Oh, the devil!

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Yes, Sir, that very identical tall squinting lady you were pleased to take me for, (curtesying) she that you addressed as the mild, modest, sentimental man of gravity, and the bold forward agreeable Rattle of the ladies club; ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Zounds, there's no bearing this; it's worse than death.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: In which of your characters, Sir, will you give us leave to address you. As the faultering gentle∣man, with looks on the ground, that speaks just to be heard, and hates hypocrisy; or the loud confi∣dent creature, that keeps it up with Mrs. Mantrap, and old Miss Biddy Buckskin, till three in the morning: ha! ha! ha!

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: O, curse on my noisy head. I never attempted to be impudent yet, that I was not taken down. I must be gone.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: By the hand of my body, but you shall not. I see it was all a mistake, and I am rejoiced to find it. You shall not, Sir, I tell you. I know she'll forgive you. Won't you forgive him, Kate. We'll all forgive you. Take courage, man.
They retire, she tormenting him to the back scene.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: So, so, they're gone off. Let them go, I care not.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Who gone?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: My dutiful niece and her gentleman, Mr. Hast∣ings, from town. He who came down with our modest visitor here.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: Who, my honest George Hastings! As worthy a fellow as lives, and the girl could not have made a more prudent choice.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Then, by the hand of my body, I'm proud of the connexion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Well, if he has taken away the lady, he has not taken her fortune, that remains in this family to console us for her loss.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Sure, Dorothy, you would not be so merce∣nary?

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Aye, but he's not of age, and she has not thought proper to wait for his refusal.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (Aside) What, returned so soon! I begin not to like it.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: (To Hardcastle) For my late attempt to fly off with your niece, let my present confusion be my punishment. We are now come back, to appeal from your justice to your humanity. By her father's consent, I first paid her my addresses, and our pas∣sions were first founded in duty.

SP.SPEAKER: Miss NEVILLE.
SP.P: Since his death, I have been obliged to stoop to dissimulation to avoid oppression. In an hour of le∣vity, I was ready even to give up my fortune to se∣cure my choice. But I'm now recover'd from the delusion, and hope from your tenderness what is de∣nied me from a nearer connexion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Pshaw, pshaw, this is all but the whining end of a modern novel.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Be it what it will, I'm glad they're come back to reclaim their due. Come hither, Tony boy. Do you refuse this lady's hand whom I now offer you?

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: What signifies my refusing. You know I can't refuse her till I'm of age, father.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: While I thought concealing your age, boy, was likely to conduce to your improvement, I concurred with your mother's desire to keep it secret. But since I find she turns it to a wrong use, I must now declare, you have been of age these three months.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Of age I Am I of age, father?

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: Above three months.

SP.SPEAKER: TONY.
SP.P: Then you'll see the first use I'll make of my liber∣ty. (Taking Miss Neville's band) Witness all men by these presents, that I, Anthony Lumpkin, es∣quire, of BLANK place, refuse you, Constantia Ne∣ville, spinster, of no place at all, for my true and lawful wife. So Constance Neville may marry whom she pleases, and Tony Lumpkin is his own man again.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir CHARLES.
SP.P: O brave 'squire!

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: My worthy friend!
Mrs. HARDCASTLE.
My undutiful offspring!

SP.SPEAKER: MARLOW.
SP.P: Joy, my dear George, I give you joy sincerely And could I prevail upon my little tyrant here to be less arbitrary, I should be the happiest man alive, if you would return me the savour.

SP.SPEAKER: HASTINGS.
SP.P: (To Miss Hardcastle) Come, madam, you are now driven to the very last scene of all your con∣trivances. I know you like him, I'm sure he loves yon, and you must and shall have him.

SP.SPEAKER: HARDCASTLE.
SP.P: (Joining their hands) And I say so too. And, Mr. Marlow, if she makes as good a wife as she has a daughter, I don't believe you'll ever repent your bargain. So now to supper. To-morrow we shall gather all the poor of the parish about us, and the mistakes of the night shall be crowned with a merry morning; so, boy, take her; and as you have been mistaken in the mistress, my wish is, that you may never be mistaken in the wife.

DIV1.HEAD: EPILOGUE.
DIV1.L: WELL, having stoop'd to conquer with success,
And gain'd a husband without aid from dress,
Still as a bar-maid, I could wish it too,
As I have conquer'd him to conquer you:
And let me say, for all your resolution,
That pretty bar-maids have done execution.
Our life is all a play, compos'd to please,
" We have our exits and our entrances."
The first act shews the simple country maid,
Harmless and young, of every thing afraid;
Blushes when hir'd, and with unmeaning action,
" I hopes as how to give you satisfaction."
Her second act displays a livelier scene.—
Th' unblushing bar-maid of a country inn,
Who whisks about the house, at market caters,
Talks loud, coquets the guests, and scolds the waiters.
Next the scene shifts to town, and there she soars,
The chop-house toast of ogling connoisieurs.
On 'squires and cits she there displays her arts,
And on the gridiron broils her lover's hearts—
And as she smiles, her triumphs to compleat,
Even common councilmen forget to eat.
The fourth act shews her wedded to the 'squire,
And madam now begins to hold it higher;
Pretends to taste, at operas cries caro,
And quits her Nancy Dawson, for Che Faro.
Doats upon dancing, and in all her pride,
Swims round the room, the Heinell of Cheapside:
Ogles and leers with artificial skill,
Till having lost in age the power to kill,
She sits all night at cards, and ogles at spadille.
Such, through our lives, the eventful history—
The fifth and last act still remains for me.
The bar-maid now for your protection prays,
Turns female Barrister, and pleads for Bays.

HEAD.STAGE: TO BE SPOKEN IN THE CHARACTER OF TONY LUMPKIN.This came too late to be spoken.

LG.L: WELL—now all's ended—and my comrades gone,
Pray what becomes of mother's nonly son?
A hopeful blade!—in town I'll fix my station,
And try to make a bluster in the nation.
As for my cousin Neville, I renounce her,
Off—in a crack—I'll carry big Bett Bouncer.
Why should not I in the great world appear?
I soon shall have a thousand pounds a year?
No matter what a man may here inherit,
In London—'gad, they have some regard to spirit.
I see the horses prancing up the streets,
And big Bett Bouncer, bobs to all she meets;
Then hoikes to jiggs and pastimes ev'ry night—
Not to the plays—they say it a'n't polite;
To Sadler's-Wells perhaps, or operas go,
And once by chance, to the roratorio.
Thus here and there, for ever up and down,
We'll set the fashions too, to half the town;
And then at auctions—money ne'er regard,
Buy pictures like the great, ten pounds a yard;
Zounds, we shall make these London gentry say,
We know what's damn'd genteel as well as they.
